datafield.subfield: A short guide to pure point diffraction in cut-and-project sets

We briefly review the diffraction of quasicrystals and then give an elementary alternative proof of the diffraction formula for regular cut-and-project sets, which is based on Bochner’s theorem from Fourier analysis. This clarifies a common view that the diffraction of a quasicrystal is determined by the diffraction of its underlying lattice. To illustrate our approach, we will also treat a number of well-known explicitly solvable examples.

(i) Given \left(G,H,\mathcal{L}\right), we have that \left(\hat{G},\hat{H},{{\mathcal{L}}^{0}}\right) is also a cut-and-project scheme. Indeed, {{\pi}^{{\hat{G}}}} is one-to-one on {{\mathcal{L}}^{0}} if and only if {{\pi}^{H}}\left(\mathcal{L}\right) is dense in H, and {{\pi}^{{\hat{H}}}}\left({{\mathcal{L}}^{0}}\right) is dense in \hat{H} if and only if {{\pi}^{G}} is one-to-one on \mathcal{L}. This is a consequence of Pontryagin duality, see e.g. [, 44: #aaa5d44bib044, section 5]

(ii) In the Euclidean setting G={{\mathbb{R}}^{d}} and H={{\mathbb{R}}^{n}}, assume that \mathcal{L} is a rotated scaled copy of {{\mathbb{Z}}^{d+n}}. Then either of the two projection assumptions implies the other by duality, compare figure, 2: #aaa5d44f02
(i) Since for a given weak model set \curlywedge (W) we can replace H by the group generated by W, the assumption that H is compactly generated is no restriction

(ii) Since we may pass from H to \overline{{{\pi}^{H}}\left(\mathcal{L}\right)}, even if the second projection assumption does not hold we can assume that {{\pi}^{H}}\left(\mathcal{L}\right) is dense in H without loss of generality. A prominent example where the second projection assumption is violated is the Penrose point set, when projected from G\times H={{\mathbb{R}}^{2+3}} and \mathcal{L} a rotated copy of {{\mathbb{Z}}^{5}}, compare [, 18: #aaa5d44bib018] and [, 4: #aaa5d44bib004, remark 7.8]. Another one-dimensional example is the period doubling point set, which will be discussed in section, 6.3: #aaa5d44s6-3

(i) The measure \text{dens}\left(\mathcal{L}\right)\centerdot {{\omega}_{\check {{h}}\,}} in the above equation is uniquely determined [, 1: #aaa5d44bib001, theorem 2.2]. It is called the Fourier transform \widehat{{{\omega}_{h}}}\in {{\mathcal{M}}^{\infty}}\left(\hat{G}\right) of {{\omega}_{h}}\in {{\mathcal{M}}^{\infty}}(G)

(ii) Note that the measure {{\omega}_{\check {{h}}\,}} has typically dense support, i.e. its Dirac point measures with positive amplitude lie dense in \hat{G}. This makes such dense Dirac combs interesting, and they have been systematically studied in [, 37: #aaa5d44bib037,, 52: #aaa5d44bib052,, 62: #aaa5d44bib062]

(i) The diffraction formula is reminiscent of the Wiener diagram for a lattice, see remark, 4.4: #aaa5d44st6. Indeed, one may first compute the Fourier transform of the window in internal space and then its squared modulus. The latter is then evaluated on the Fourier module, which is the dual of the underlying lattice projected to the direct space
(ii) The diffraction formula might no longer be valid if the second projection assumption is violated

(i) For any character \chi :G\to \mathbb{C} we have {{\sigma}_{\chi}}={{\delta}_{\chi}}, the Dirac point measure in \chi \in \hat{G}. In particular, any nonnegative constant function is positive definite

(ii) For any pointwise product {{\varphi}_{1}}\centerdot {{\varphi}_{2}} where both {{\varphi}_{1}} and {{\varphi}_{2}} are continuous and positive definite, we have {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}\centerdot {{\varphi}_{2}}}}={{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}}}\ast {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}

(iii) For any convolution {{\varphi}_{1}}\ast {{\varphi}_{2}} where {{\varphi}_{1}} is continuous positive definite and {{\varphi}_{2}}\in PK(G), we have {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}\ast {{\varphi}_{2}}}}=\widehat{{{\varphi}_{1}}}\centerdot {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}=\widehat{{{\varphi}_{2}}}\centerdot {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}}}, compare [, 14: #aaa5d44bib014, proposition 4.3]. Indeed \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} {{{\int}^{}}_{{\hat{G}}}}\chi (x) & \,\text{d}{{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}\ast {{\varphi}_{2}}}}(\chi )={{\varphi}_{1}}\ast {{\varphi}_{2}}(x)={\int}_{G}{{\varphi}_{1}}(t){{\varphi}_{2}}(x-t)\,\text{d}t \\ {} & ={\int}_{G}{{\varphi}_{1}}(t){\int}_{{\hat{G}}}\chi (x-t)\,\text{d}{{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}(\chi )\,\text{d}t \\ {} & ={\int}_{{\hat{G}}}{\int}_{G}{{\varphi}_{1}}(t)\overline{\chi (t)}\,\text{d}t\,\chi (x)\,\text{d}{{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}(\chi ) \\ {} & ={\int}_{{\hat{G}}}\chi (x)\widehat{{{\varphi}_{1}}}(\chi )\,\text{d}{{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}(\chi )={\int}_{{\hat{G}}}\chi (x)\,\text{d}\left(\widehat{{{\varphi}_{1}}}\centerdot {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}\right)(\chi ), \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*} where Fubini can be used by positivity or because {{\varphi}_{2}} has compact support. This shows that {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{1}}\ast {{\varphi}_{2}}}}=\widehat{{{\varphi}_{1}}}\centerdot {{\sigma}_{{{\varphi}_{2}}}}. The other identity is shown similarly

(iv) For any f\ast \tilde{f} where f\in {{L}^{2}}(G) is compactly supported, we have {{\sigma}_{f\ast \tilde{{f}}\,}}=\,|\,\check {{f}}\,{{|}^{2}}\centerdot {{\theta}_{G}} by example, B.2: #aaa5d44st22

(v) For any pointwise product g\odot h where both g\in C(G) and h\in C(H) are positive definite, we have {{\sigma}_{g\odot h}}={{\sigma}_{g}}\otimes {{\sigma}_{h}}, the product measure of {{\sigma}_{g}} and {{\sigma}_{h}} in \mathcal{M}\left(\hat{G}\times \hat{H}\right)

(i) The measure {{\delta}_{0}} is positive definite as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} \langle {{\delta}_{0}},f\ast \tilde{f}\rangle =f\ast \tilde{f}(0)={\int}_{G}|\,f(x){{|}^{2}}\text{d}x\geqslant 0. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*}
(ii) Any Haar measure {{\theta}_{G}} is positive definite as \langle {{\theta}_{G}},f\ast \tilde{{f}}\,\rangle =\,|\langle {{\theta}_{G}},f\rangle {{|}^{2}}\geqslant 0

(iii) Let H\subseteq G be a closed subgroup of G and let {{\theta}_{H}} be a Haar measure on {{\theta}_{H}} is positive definite on H. But {{\theta}_{H}}, viewed as a measure on G, is also positive definite. This holds since for f\in {{C}_{c}}(G), we have f{{|}_{H}}\in {{C}_{c}}(H) for its restriction to H

(iv) If μ is a finite measure, then \mu \ast \tilde{\mu} is positive definite as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} \langle \mu \ast \tilde{{\mu}}\,,\,f\ast \tilde{{f}}\,\rangle =\langle {{\theta}_{G}},|\,\tilde{{f}}\,\ast \mu {{|}^{2}}\rangle \geqslant 0. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \end{equation*}

(i) For the convenience of the reader, we did not use the above theorem in this article but developed Fourier theory for model sets from scratch, based on Bochner's theorem for positive definite functions. The first step of our proof of the Poisson summation formula in proposition, 4.1: #aaa5d44st1, however, is a crucial ingredient of a proof of theorem, 10: #aaa5d44st39

(ii) There exists a theory of positive definite measures on certain non-abelian groups, which is also based on some version of Bochner's theorem [, 63: #aaa5d44bib063, chapter 9]. It has recently been used for harmonic analysis of non-abelian model sets [, 17: #aaa5d44bib017]

(iii) Fourier analysis of unbounded measures beyond the positive definite case is developed by Argabright and de Lamadrid [, 1: #aaa5d44bib001]. There transformability of \mu \in \mathcal{M}(G) is defined by requiring equation (, C.2: #aaa5d44eqn076) to hold for some {{\sigma}_{\mu}}\in \mathcal{M}\left(\hat{G}\right). The transform is always a translation bounded measure [, 1: #aaa5d44bib001, theorem 2.5]. It is an open question whether any such μ is a linear combination of positive definite measures, compare the discussion in [, 1: #aaa5d44bib001, page 29]

(iv) For example, equation (, C.2: #aaa5d44eqn076) with \mu ={{\delta}_{g}} reduces to the Fourier inversion formula, and we get \hat{\mu}=g\centerdot {{\theta}_{{\hat{G}}}}, where g:\hat{G}\to \mathbb{C} is understood as g(\chi )=\chi (g)
We dedicate this work to Tony Guttmann on the occasion of his 70th birthday
The cited monograph is a very useful compendium about mathematical quasicrystals and, more generally, on mathematics of aperiodic order
A realistic modelling at small wavelengths has to incorporate absorption cross ratios [, 24: #aaa5d44bib024]
Vague convergence means {{\omega}_{n}}(\,f)\to \omega (\,f) for all continuous compactly supported functions f

In fact \mathcal{S} is a non-regular model set: since no component of W is maximal, the compact window has empty interior. We thus have W=\partial W and hence {{\theta}_{H}}(\partial W)>0. This also indicates that \mathcal{S} has positive configurational entropy [, 28: #aaa5d44bib028,, 49: #aaa5d44bib049], which might seem to contradict pure point diffractivity. But \mathcal{S} has in fact zero Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy with respect to the natural pattern frequency measure [, 6: #aaa5d44bib006,, 7: #aaa5d44bib007,, 31: #aaa5d44bib031]
See appendix C for some background on measures
